Description:
On the Docket expands public access to the United States Supreme Court by transforming the audio recordings of its decisions into video. 

Using AI-generated visuals and the justicesâ€™ official recorded opinions, we present videos of the justices delivering their opinions, making these pivotal moments more engaging to a broader audience. 

Subscribe and like to be notified of new videos.

Photo: Exterior of the U.S. Supreme Court by Joe Ravi (CC BY-SA 3.0)

File Name: Trump v. US: Justice Roberts Opinion
Post Title: Trump v. US: Justice Roberts Opinion
Description:
SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS

Watch Chief Justice Roberts announce the Opinion for the Supreme Court's ruling in Trump v. United States (2024) fundamentally altered presidential power by establishing that Presidents have absolute immunity from criminal prosecution for "official acts" performed within their core constitutional authority.

The Court created a tiered system: absolute immunity for core duties, presumptive immunity for other official acts, and no immunity for unofficial (private) acts. This decision ensures Presidents can take ""bold and unhesitating"" action without fear of future prosecution, but critics argue it places the Executive above the law.

The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI.

On the Docket expands public access to the United States Supreme Court by transforming its decisions into video using the justices' actual voices. Although the Court promptly releases audio of oral arguments, it bans video and does not post recordings of opinion announcements, limiting access to those present in the courtroom. These recordings are instead withheld for months before release to the National Archives. On the Docket fills this gap by converting the justices' audio into engaging videos. Using AI-generated visuals, we present representations of the justices delivering their opinions, making these pivotal moments more accessible to the public.

#SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket

File Name: Trump v. US: Justice Sotomayor Dissent
Post Title: Trump v. US: Justice Sotomayor Dissent
Description:
SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS

Watch Justice Sotomayor summarize her dissent in Trump v. United States. It argues that the majority Opinion creates a "law-free zone" around the Presidency. By granting absolute immunity for core official acts, the dissenters claim the Court effectively insulated the President from criminal accountability, violating the principle that no one is above the law.

Sotomayor warns that a President could now order the assassination of a political rival or organize a military coup with functional impunity, as long as the actions are framed as official duties, leaving the Republic vulnerable.

The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI.

For the first time, the Court must determine whether and to what extent a former president is immune from criminal prosecution for official conduct.

The majority reasons that exposing presidents to criminal prosecution for official acts would distort executive decision-making and unduly burden the presidency.

"SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS

The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI.

#SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket"

The majority holds that separation of powers grants the President presumptive immunity for official acts, unless prosecution poses no intrusion on executive authority. SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI. #SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket

The Court rejects the dissentsâ€™ warnings as overstated, maintaining that it merely recognizes limited presidential immunity required by the separation of powers. SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI. #SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket

The Court contends that without immunity, successive presidents could weaponize criminal prosecutions against their predecessors for official decisions.

SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI. #SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket
Invoking Washingtonâ€™s warning against factional revenge, the majority frames its decision as protecting the presidencyâ€™s institutional integrity rather than any individual officeholder.

The majority holds that while the President is not above the law, he cannot be criminally prosecuted for core constitutional powers and enjoys presumptive immunity for official acts, vacating and remanding the case against him.

Post Title: The events alleged in the indictment are unprecedented
Description: The question facing the Court today is one that it has never had to answer before in this nation's history.

The Constitution rejects invented immunity: The majorityâ€™s arguments collapse because the Constitution provides no textual basis for criminal immunity for former presidents.

"SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS

The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI.

#SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket

Founding-era sources confirm that former presidents were understood to remain subject to ordinary criminal prosecution. SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI. #SCOTUS #creativeAI #OntheDocket

The majority elevates separation-of-powers concerns to impose near-absolute immunity, making it virtually impossible to prosecute a former president for official acts. SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI. #scotus #creativeAI #OntheDocket
The Court frees the president from the very laws he must enforce.

Even officials granted civil immunity remain subject to criminal prosecution to preserve equality before the law, a principle especially vital when a former president is accused of abusing public power.
Under the majorityâ€™s doctrine, even a president impeached and convicted for egregious misconduct would retain presumptive criminal immunity for official acts.

The majority invents sweeping new protections, including barring official-acts evidence, adopting the broadest imaginable view of presidential immunity and applying it as a one-way ratchet that only expands executive protection.
The majority eagerly secures immunity yet balks at denying it for plainly private conduct, calling the issue too difficult even after contrary concessions.
By creating sweeping official-acts immunity, the Court risks placing the president above the law and invites abuses the Framers sought to prevent.
For the first time, former presidents are granted immunity from criminal accountability, leaving democracy without its traditional legal safeguard.

File Name: Trump v. CASA Inc.: Justice Barrett Opinion
Description:
SUBSCRIBEâ–¶ï¸Ž https://www.youtube.com/@OnTheDocket-SCOTUS

The Court held that the Judiciary Act of 1789 does not grant federal courts the authority to issue universal injunctions, partially staying three preliminary injunctions against a birthright citizenship executive order to the extent they extended beyond the named plaintiffs, while expressly not ruling on the merits of the order itself. 

The audio is genuine, recorded in the US Supreme Court. The animation was made with AI.

Description:

Justice Sotomayor argued that the majority was wrong to strip courts of the power to issue universal injunctions â€” especially in this case, where every court to consider the birthright citizenship executive order found it patently unconstitutional â€” and warned that the decision hamstrings the judiciary from fully blocking enforcement of plainly unlawful executive policies, urging affected parties to pursue class action relief instead.
